item.title: Is the optimal magnetic rectangle a square?
item.description: arXiv:2508.16152v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We are concerned with the dependence of the lowest eigenvalue of the magnetic Dirichlet Laplacian on the geometry of rectangles, subject to homogeneous fields. We conjecture that the square is a global minimiser both under the area or perimeter constraints. Contrary to the well-known magnetic-free analogue, the present spectral problem does not admit explicit solutions. By establishing lower and upper bound to the eigenvalue, we establish the conjecture for weak magnetic fields. Moreover, we relate the validity of the conjecture to the simplicity of the eigenvalue and symmetries of minimisers of a non-convex minimisation problem.
item.dc:creator: David Krejcirik

item.title: Sharp bounds on the failure of the hot spots conjecture
item.description: arXiv:2508.16321v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The hot spots ratio of a domain $\Omega\subset \mathbb{R}^d$ measures the degree of failure of Rauch's hot spots conjecture on that domain. We identify the largest possible value of this ratio over all connected Lipschitz domains $\Omega\subset \mathbb{R}^d$, for any dimension $d$. As $d\to \infty$, we show that this maximal ratio converges to $\sqrt{e}$, which asymptotically matches the previous best known upper bound by Mariano, Panzo and Wang. For $d\ge 2$, we show that sets extremizing the hot spots ratio do not exist, and extremizing sequences must converge to a ball at a quantitative rate. We then give a sharp bound on the measure of the set for which the first Neumann eigenfunction exceeds its maximal boundary value. From this we deduce that the hot spots conjecture is asymptotically true "in measure'' as $d\to \infty$.
item.dc:creator: Jaume de Dios Pont, Alexander W. Hsu, Mitchell A. Taylor

item.title: Geodesic nets via eigenvalue optimisation
item.description: arXiv:2508.16331v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We explore a connection between geodesic nets and quantum graphs optimising certain functionals from spectral theory. For surfaces, critical metrics for the normalised $k^{\mathrm{th}}$ eigenvalue of the Laplacian give rise to isometric minimal immersions to a unit sphere. In this spirit we obtain geodesic nets from optimal quantum graphs, and obstructions to the existence of critical metrics.
item.dc:creator: Duc Hoang Cao

item.title: On the asymptotic behavior of the spectral gap for discrete Schr\"odinger operators
item.description: arXiv:2508.16353v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this note we elaborate on the convergence of the spectral gap of a class of discrete Schr\"odinger operators defined on a path graph in the limit of infinite volume. We confirm and extend recent results on the convergence of the spectral gap to a larger class of potentials using entirely different methods. Most importantly, we also resolve a conjecture previously proposed in this context. This then yields new insights into the rate at which the spectral gap tends to zero as the volume increases.
item.dc:creator: Matthias Hofmann, Joachim Kerner, Maximilian Pechmann

item.title: Eigenvalues of the Neumann magnetic Laplacian in the unit disk
item.description: arXiv:2411.11721v4 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this paper, we study the first eigenvalue of the magnetic Laplacian with Neumann boundary conditions in the unit disk $\mathbb D$ in $\mathbb R^2$. There is a rather complete asymptotic analysis when the constant magnetic field tends to $+\infty$ and some inequalities seem to hold for any value of this magnetic field, leading to rather simple conjectures. Our goal is to explore these questions by revisiting a classical picture of the physicist D. Saint-James theoretically and numerically. On the way, we revisit the asymptotic analysis in light of the asymptotics obtained by Fournais-Helffer, that we can improve by combining them with a formula stated by Saint-James.
item.arxiv:journal_reference: "Eigenvalues of the Neumann magnetic Laplacian in the unit disk," Journal of Mathematical Physics (Vol.66, Issue 8), 2025
item.dc:creator: Bernard Helffer, Corentin L\'ena
